none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from T. M. Scott, July 31, 1889
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from T. M. Scott, July 31, 1889
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 28 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: Personal letter from T. M. Scott, Agent of the Board at the Texas Agricultural and Mechanical College Agricultural Experiment Station, to Louis L. McInnis, Chairman of the Faculty, written during McInnis's vacation at Montgomery Springs, Virginia. Scott expresses hope that McInnis and his wife are enjoying their rest, shares philosophical reflections on happiness and gratitude, and provides updates on campus operations including progress on the Assembly Hall, staffing matters, and the health of various individuals. The letter reflects the collegial relationship between Scott and McInnis and offers glimpses into daily life at the early Texas A&M institution in 1889.

body.value:
[Header]

Agricultural Experiment Station of the
STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE
OF TEXAS.
(TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.)

LOUIS L. McINNIS,
Chairman of the Faculty.
T. M. SCOTT,
Agent of the Board.
F. A. GULLEY,
Director of the Station.
Agricultural Experiment Station Council.

Address Correspondence to
PROF. F. A. GULLEY,
DIRECTOR OF STATION.

[Body]

College Station, Texas, July 31st, 1889
Prof. L. L. McInnis.
Montgomery Springs Va.

My dear friend
I thought, until I got your note to
day, and hoped, that you had for-
gotten everything at the College.
And that you and Mrs McInnis
were so enjoying yourselves, just
you two, like you were when you
were sweethearts togeather, that no
one could think one unkind thought
if during your entire stay at the
Springs you never thought of them,
let alone abstracting yourself long
enough to write. If I were in your
place, the only thoughts I would
have would be of where you are
and further up the mountain side,

**Transcription Analysis and Interpretation**

Alright, let's break this down. I'm looking at this image, and it's a handwritten letter on what is clearly official letterhead. The header's got all the typical elements: the name of the "Agricultural Experiment Station of the STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE OF TEXAS" (capitalized, of course!), its technical branch, and all the names and titles of key figures – Chairman, Agent, Director, and the Station Council. We've got the usual contact information: "Address Correspondence to PROF. F. A. GULLEY, DIRECTOR OF STATION."

The key here is the date: "College Station, Texas, July 31<sup>st</sup> 1889". And here's where it gets interesting: the recipient. The letter is addressed to "Prof. L. L. McInnis". At first, I thought that initial was an "S", especially looking at the handwriting of "Springs" later on. However, considering the context of the letterhead, where "Louis L. McInnis" is listed as Chairman of the Faculty, and the salutation "My dear friend" combined with the fact that these are the only initialed letters in the handwriting: I'm pretty sure it's "L. L.". The way it’s written *could* be an "S", but based on the letterhead and the period style in which the letter is written, I'm fairly certain the writer is addressing the Chairman or at least someone closely connected to him. This initial is far more likely a stylized cursive "L". Also, considering the Mrs. McInnis reference. I'm going with "L. L." to match the header. It looks like it is written as "S. S." in the letter. But the context is clear.

Now, let's transcribe the body: "My dear friend / I thought, until I got your note to / day, and hoped, that you had for- / gotten everything at the College. / and that you and Mrs McInnis / were so enjoying yourselves, just / you two, like you were when you / were sweethearts togeather, that no / one could think one unkind thought / if during your entire stay at the / Springs you never thought of them, / let alone abstracting yourself long / enough to write. If I were in your / place, the only thoughts I would / have would be of where you are / and further up the mountain side," and it looks like a comma is on the last line, implying the next page of the letter. This is all standard stuff, a friendly, familiar tone, and some implied nostalgia. Spelling error in "togeather". Looks all correct, really. The handwritten form is all there, line breaks and formatting included. I’ll make sure to get the "31<sup>st</sup>" correct, and mark those commas and periods and capitalizations carefully. I think I've got this.

When I was a little fellow I used
to look up the tall trees and to the
high hill tops and think how close
up to the sky they were. I don't
believe the knowlege that it is
farther up to heaven than I thought
it was when a boy has added any
thing to my happiness. Though the
world has been a very pleasant
one to me. The sunshing day have
far out numbered the cloudy
one, And I thank you and Mrs
McTunis for opening the clouds
many a time, and letting the
blue sky through. May God be
kind to both of you and give
you sunny days.

Matters here are going along
all right. Hutchinson does very
well in the Office, and the work to
be done has been provided for.
Assembly hall, is being roofed,
Subers, has not worked at the fence.
Gulley has gone. Dr Francis starts
to night to Set load cattle for Mo.

**Transcription Complete** Okay, here's what I've got. I've analyzed the handwritten letter, taking it line by line. I'm focusing on accuracy, so I'm maintaining the original spelling (even the misspelling of "knowlege") and punctuation, including any unusual letter formations. I'm keeping the original line breaks using `
` tags and separating the two paragraphs with `

` tags. I've made some observations about potentially ambiguous letters, like the name "McTunis," which is how it *visually* appears in the script, even though a more common name might be expected. I've also noted the unusual word "sunshing" and chosen to transcribe it as is, since it looks like a "g" and the writer did not write "y." Likewise, I am keeping "Set load cattle" and am not changing it. After careful consideration of letter formation, comparison with other examples in the text, and considering the likely meaning, here is my final transcription:

When I was a little fellow I used
to look up the tall trees and to the
high hill tops and think how close
up to the sky they were. I don't
believe the knowlege that it is
farther up to heaven than I thought
it was when a boy has added any
thing to my happiness. Though the
world has been a very pleasant
one to me. The sunshing day have
far out numbered the cloudy
one, And I thank you and Mrs
McTunis for opening the clouds
many a time, and letting the
blue sky through. May God be
kind to both of you and give
you sunny days.

Matters here are going along
all right. Hutchinson does very
well in the Office, and the work to
be done has been provided for.
Assembly hall, is being roofed,
Subers, has not worked at the fence.
Gulley has gone. Dr Francis starts
to night to Set load cattle for Mo.

Agricultural Experiment Station of the
STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE
OF TEXAS. [1889, July 31]
(TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.)

LOUIS L. McINNIS,
Chairman of the Faculty.
T. M. SCOTT,
Agent of the Board.
F. A. GULLEY,
Director of the Station.
Agricultural Experiment Station Council.

Address Correspondence to
PROF. F A. GULLEY,
DIRECTOR OF STATION.

College Station, Texas, .............................., 188

to night, will go with them, and
from Columbia, on to Cincinati
for furlough.

There is nothing of interest
going on about which to write
you. The weather of course
exceedingly hot. has not rained
since you went away.
Paul Braun is sick in bed
Measles, Guenther, returned last
night. Harrington will not go for
a couple weeks. Mrs Scott, in
Collin Co.

Kind regards to Mrs McInnis
and yourself.
Write when you want any-
thing done,

Your friend
T.M. Scott.

Kiss the little ones for me
when you see them.

**Detailed Transcription of a Handwritten Letter**

Alright, I'm diving into this transcription with a methodical approach, starting with a careful dissection of the letterhead. I see at the top, centered, "Agricultural Experiment Station of the," followed by larger text: "STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE," and then "OF TEXAS." with "(TECHNICAL BRANCH OF THE UNIVERSITY.)" below. The handwritten date, "[1889, July 31]", is to the right of "OF TEXAS." and it's important to include the brackets; the style of handwriting looks consistent.

On the left, there's a column of names and titles: "LOUIS L. McINNIS, Chairman of the Faculty.", "T. M. SCOTT, Agent of the Board.", "F. A. GULLEY, Director of the Station.", and finally, "Agricultural Experiment Station Council."

On the right, we have: "Address Correspondence to" followed by "PROF. F. A. GULLEY, DIRECTOR OF STATION." - I note the "F A." rather than "F. A." in the right side header compared to "F. A. GULLEY" on the left column.

A decorative line separates this header information from the dateline, which reads: "College Station, Texas, .............., 188..." However, the handwritten text begins immediately below this line, so I'll need to account for this. The "188" is printed.

Now, into the handwritten body of the letter. It appears to start mid-thought or continuation from a previous page, but the structure is obvious. It begins, "to night, will go with them, and" - the two-word phrasing for "tonight" is typical of the era, and it's clearly not a formal opening like "Dear X." The writer jumps right in.

The text continues: "from Columbia, on to Cincinati for furlough." I have to double-check "Cincinati" because it's a bit ambiguous. After careful examination of the strokes, the writer seems to have written a slightly unconventional, but recognizable, "Cincinati" instead of "Cincinnati". I will be true to the original. "for furlough." completes the paragraph.

Next, "There is nothing of interest going on about which to write you. The weather of course exceedingly hot. has not rained since you went away." - I note the indentation, the lowercase "h" in "has" and that "exceedingly" is split "ex-ceedingly".

Moving on: "Paul Braun is sick in bed Measles, Guenther, returned last night. Harrington will not go for a couple weeks. Mrs Scott, in Collin Co. Kind regards to Mrs McInnis and yourself, Write when you want any- thing done, Your friend T.M. Scott. Kiss the little ones for me when you see them."

I'm confirming specific transcriptions: "Guenther," there's a comma after the name as I see it, so I'll include it. "Harrington" and "McInnis" are clear. The "M" in "McInnis" appears as a capital M, then a small "c", and "Innis". Also, there's a comma after "Scott" and a period after "Co" in "Collin Co." The letter ends with a standard closing, then the signature of "T.M. Scott" - which I confirm matches the "T. M. SCOTT" in the letterhead. Finally, the post-script: "Kiss the little ones..." at the bottom-left, under "Your friend" but to the left of the signature.

I will use HTML tags as requested, while maintaining the structural layout. Since the prompt does not restrict attribute use explicitly, I can assume standard attributes are usable on accepted tags such as `p`. Therefore, I will transcribe and render the HTML now. The image should resemble the letterhead by using breaks and other tags, and keeping to the IIIF guidelines. I will maintain the paragraph structure.
